Notes: Snap lockdown means schools closed through Monday, April 26 - ""The following facilities are closed:... Schools, universities, TAFEs and education facilities (other than residential schools)""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425132208/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown    http://web.archive.org/web/20210425124249/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/publications/covid-19-coronavirus-three-day-lockdown-frequently-asked-questions-faq

The Western Australian government announced that people in Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must enter into a lockdown from 12.01am Saturday, April 24, to limit any potential spread of COVID-19. The lock-down was announced in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The lock-down announced was planned for 3 days, and is scheduled to end at 12.01am Tuesday, April 27.    STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST) DIRECTIONS were inforce for the duration of the lockdown and stipulated that schools, universities or education institutions must close.  Except for the extent that the institution provides accommodation for students.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502061717/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/20210423-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.    Restrictions for schools and universities during this period are:     Schools, childcare centres and TAFEs open - mask-wearing requirements apply for all school staff and secondary students, but not primary school students or staff when teaching  Universities open for online learning only    These restrictions were enforced by the SAFE TRANSITION FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA DIRECTIONS (NO 2) These directions come into effect at 12.01 am on Tuesday, 27 April 2021.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502074436/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Safe-transition-for%20Western-Australia-Directions-No2.pdf

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    During this period:   Schools, childcare centres, universities and TAFEs are open  Mask wearing requirements apply for all school staff and secondary students, but not primary school students or staff when teaching.  …”school, university, educational institution or childcare facility that is necessary for the normal business of the facility;” are exempt from gathering rules stipulated by the Gathering and Restricted Activities direction (No.2) which is currently in force for Perth, the Peel Region, and Rottnest Island.   Therefore have reverted to a zero code.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further   https://web.archive.org/web/20210419114440/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/090421-Gathering-and-Activities-Directions-No2.pdf

Each State and Territory jurisdiction in Australian has legal directions enforcing COVID-19 restrictions around gatherings and/or workplace operations.  However, there are currently no directions inforce that disrupt the usual (pre-COVID) functions of schools and universities.  Archived links are provided to the relevant directs currently in place for each jurisdiction. Queensland:   In a loosening of restrictions The Restrictions for Queensland Direction (No. 2) was revoked from 6:00am on 15 April 2021.   Restrictions on Businesses, Activities and Undertakings Direction (No. 18) are effective from 6am AEST 15 April 2021.  With exceptions this directions provides for a general density quotient for Queensland workplaces of 1 person per 2 square meters.   This is up to date as of 23rd April 2021. Updated archived links provided.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423030727/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/business-activity-undertaking-direction     Victoria:    In a modest loosening of restrictions the Workplace Directions (No 24) commenced at 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021.    With limited exceptions, these directions set a general requirement that workplaces must adhere to a density quotient of 1 person per 2 square meters.  Workplace (Additional Industry Obligations) Directions (No 21) commence at 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021.  These directions provide more stringent restrictions for the following specific:   (a) poultry processing facilities; and  (b) abattoirs and meat processing facilities; and  (c) seafood processing facilities; and  (d) supermarket Work Premises and perishable food Work Premises;  and  (e) warehousing and distribution centres; and  (f) commercial cleaning services; and  (g) commercial passenger vehicle services; and  (h) horticulture operations using seasonal workers for seasonal  horticultural work; and  (i) care facilities; and  (j) ports of entry servicing international arrivals; and  (k) hotel quarantine; and  (l) hospitals; and  (m) Australian air transport operators.     An example of additional restrictions provided for by this direction are: ""(i) developing separate shifts in a way that minimises physical  interactions between groups of workers attending different shifts;  (ii) separates workers into work areas;  (iii) dividing work areas up further into separate teams;  (iv) providing separate break areas for the separate teams;   Workplace (Additional Industry Obligations) Directions (No 21) 5 of 19  (v) requiring teams to use separate entrances and exits from other  teams;  (vi) where workers are from the same household, ensuring they work  in the same shift and work area;  ""    This is up to date as of 23rd April 2021. Updated archived links provided.   Particularly due to these additional restrictions in place in Victoria, C2 coded as a T1.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423030856/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/victorias-restriction-levels-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419122032/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2024%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf

Gyms and indoor sporting venues, playgrounds, skate parks and outdoor recreational facilities, as well as cultural venues such as cinemas and libraries, will all be closed.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community    http://web.archive.org/web/20210425132208/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

The Western Australian government announced that people in Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must enter into a lockdown from 12.01am Saturday, April 24, to limit any potential spread of COVID-19. The lock-down was announced in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The lock-down announced was planned for 3 days, and is scheduled to end at 12.01am Tuesday, April 27.    STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST) DIRECTIONS were in force for the duration of the lockdown and stipulated that all non-essential workplaces must close (or employees must work remotely).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502061717/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/20210423-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.    Restrictions for workplaces in place during this period are:   20-patron capacity limit and 4sqm rule for: cafes, restaurants, bars and pubs for seated food and drink service only. Beauty salons, hairdressers and barbers. Public venues such as recreation centres, outdoor playgrounds, museums and swimming pools. Places of worship. Entertainment venues.   No visitors to aged and disability care facilities and hospitals, except for compassionate reasons and advocacy  Weddings and funerals can proceed with up to 100 guests, but require an exemption.   Professional and community sports, including training, permitted but without spectators  Elective surgery can proceed for category 1 and urgent category 2 surgeries only  Schools, childcare centres and TAFEs open - mask-wearing requirements apply for all school staff and secondary students, but not primary school students or staff when teaching  Universities open for online learning only  Fitness clubs, gyms, casinos and nightclubs remain closed    These restrictions were enforced by the SAFE TRANSITION FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA DIRECTIONS (NO 2) These directions come into effect at 12.01 am on Tuesday, 27 April 2021.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502074436/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Safe-transition-for%20Western-Australia-Directions-No2.pdf

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    During this period:   All businesses, workplaces and higher education can now reopen.  Seated hospitality venues, including restaurants, cafés, food courts and bars that provide seated service only, can open at 75 per cent capacity or apply the 2sqm rule – whichever is greater  Gyms, fitness centres, dance studios, beauty salons, hairdressers can open with the 2sqm rule in place  Public venues, including, community centres, libraries, museums, galleries, recreation centres, can open with the 2sqm rule in place.  Nightclubs can open subject to the 4sqm rule, with masks mandatory  Major stadiums, including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena and HBF Park can operate at 75 per cent capacity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    It was initially announced that during this period all businesses, workplaces and higher education can now reopen.  However, subsequently on the 2nd May at 11:35am the Additional Measures (Closure of Certain Premises) Directions were enacted.  These directions require all WA major stadiums, the casinos and nightclubs to close until 12:01am on 8 May 2021, provided that the West Coast Eagles v Fremantle match on 2 May 2021 may proceed without crowds.    The change came after a quarantine hotel security guard and two of his close contacts tested positive to COVID-19.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084012/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/Additional-Measures-Closure-of-Certain-Premises-Directions.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084305/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-05-02/no-crowds-at-perth-stadium-for-western-derby/100110712

Western Australia  In a tightening of restrictions, on the 2nd May 2021 at 11:35am the Additional Measures (Closure of Certain Premises) Directions were enacted.  These directions require all WA major stadiums, the casinos and nightclubs to close until 12:01am on 8 May 2021, provided that the West Coast Eagles v Fremantle match on 2 May 2021 may proceed without crowds.    The change came after a quarantine hotel security guard and two of his close contacts tested positive to COVID-19.    This remains up to date as of the 7th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084012/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/Additional-Measures-Closure-of-Certain-Premises-Directions.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084305/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-05-02/no-crowds-at-perth-stadium-for-western-derby/100110712

Western Australia:  On the 6th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing ""The easing of restrictions for Perth and Peel will proceed as planned from 12.01am Saturday, May 8. Following three COVID-19 cases detected in Perth over the weekend, the Chief Health Officer has advised Perth and Peel will need to see through the full 14-day incubation period, from the last case detected, which ends 12.01am Saturday, May 15, 2021.""  In part, this announcement included the relaxation of previous workplace closing requirements for stadiums, night clubs, and casinos.  ""The following transitional restrictions are set to take effect from 12.01am Saturday, May 8:…  The casino gaming floor can reopen subject to the two square metre rule;  Nightclubs can open subject to the two square metre rule;  100-person limit in all homes, for private indoor or outdoor gatherings;  Major stadiums, including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena and HBF Park can operate at 75 per cent capacity, with masks mandatory.  “  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517111820/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Restrictions-set-to-significantly-ease-from-12-01am-Saturday-May-8.aspx    Therefore, revert to a 1T code.  Some, but not all, other Australian state and territory jurisdictions have requirements in place that meet threshold for a 1 code.  The Northern Territory is provided as an example of a jurisdiction that does not meet threshold for a 1 code on this indicator.      The Northern Territory  Businesses in the Northern Territory must lodge a COVID-19 Safety Plan.   According to the COVID-19 Directions (No. 56) 2020: Safety Measures for Places, Businesses, Activities, Services and Premises – COVID-19 Safety Plans must include: details of the primary contact person/person responsible for making sure COVID-19 safety requiements are followed; details of sanitation facilities; details of signage displayed at the business to remind staff and vistors of covid safe practices; to document how where possible social distancing is encouraged.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517122741/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/951879/cho-directions-no56-safety-measures-places-businesses-activities-services-premises.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517122424/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/business

Western Australia:  On the 13th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing "" From 12.01am Saturday, May 15, Perth and Peel will return to pre-lockdown life.""  The Western Australian COVID-19 Government Website further states that “There will be no capacity limits for weddings and funerals;  Major stadiums including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena, HBF Park and HBF Stadium – main arena can operate at 100 per cent capacity;  Visitor limits for patients in hospital, aged care or disability facilities will be lifted;”  However, also according to the Western Australian COVID-19 government website, some modest capacity restrictions do remain in place for some workplaces.  This includes the 2 square meter rule for the following venues: Nightclubs; Unseated bars; Unseated events/festivals (music, beer, wine, cultural etc.); Galleries; Museums; Libraries; Sport and recreation facilities including gyms, recreation centres, group fitness classes and indoor and outdoor swimming pools; Amusement parks; Wildlife parks and Perth Zoo; Function centres; Community, recreation or youth centres or facilities, including but not limited to community halls, sporting clubs, Returned and Services League facilities, and Police and Community Youth Centres; Adult entertainment premises, including but not limited to strip clubs, brothels and sex on premises venues; Casino and gambling venues; Arcades; Funeral parlours; Events that involve unfixed seating (e.g. BYO chair concerts).  The following hospitality venues are subject to a 75% capacity rule: Restaurants; Hotels (excluding bottleshops); Cafes; Food courts; Bars with seated service only.  While modest, these square meter rules and capacity limitations continue to meet threshold for a 1 code.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210517121029/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Pre-lockdown-life-to-resume-in-full-from-12-01am-this-Saturday.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517121130/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/pre-lockdown-life-resumes-perth-and-peel-regions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517124028/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do     Some, but not all, other Australian state and territory jurisdictions have requirements in place that meet threshold for a 1 code.  The Northern Territory is provided as an example of a jurisdiction that does not meet threshold for a 1 code on this indicator.      The Northern Territory  Businesses in the Northern Territory must lodge a COVID-19 Safety Plan.   According to the COVID-19 Directions (No. 56) 2020: Safety Measures for Places, Businesses, Activities, Services and Premises – COVID-19 Safety Plans must include: details of the primary contact person/person responsible for making sure COVID-19 safety requiements are followed; details of sanitation facilities; details of signage displayed at the business to remind staff and vistors of covid safe practices; to document how where possible social distancing is encouraged.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517122741/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/951879/cho-directions-no56-safety-measures-places-businesses-activities-services-premises.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517122424/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/business

Queensland:   In a loosening of restrictions The Restrictions for Queensland Direction (No. 2) was revoked from 6:00am on 15 April 2021.   Restrictions on Businesses, Activities and Undertakings Direction (No. 18) are effective from 6am AEST 15 April 2021.    In part this Directions provides:   No limit for people gathering in outdoor public spaces across Queensland.  One person per 2m2 (e.g. restaurants, cafés, pubs, clubs, museums, art galleries, places of worship, convention centres and Parliament House), including standing, eating and drinking.  Indoor events: 500 people permitted at indoor events with a COVID Safe Event Checklist. Larger events require a COVID Safe Plan.  Ticketed venues: 100% capacity at allocated seated, ticketed venues with patrons encouraged to wear masks on entry and exit (e.g. theatre, live music, cinemas, indoor sports, universities and other higher education institutions). Performers can distance from audience at 2m, except choirs which remain at 4m from the audience.  Dancing: Dancing is allowed in all indoor and outdoor venues including pubs, beer gardens, clubs and nightclubs, subject to the one person per 2m2 rule.  Outdoor dance festivals and music festivals: Fewer than 500 people per day permitted without a COVID Safe Checklist, no requirement to collect contact details. Events with between 500 and 1499 people permitted with a COVID Safe Event Checklist. Larger events require a COVID Safe Event Plan.  Outdoor events: Anzac Day parades, fetes, fun runs and other outdoor only events do not need a COVID Safe Event Checklist or Event Plan.  Open air stadiums: 100% allocated seated and ticketed capacity (with a COVID Safe Plan). All patrons encouraged to wear masks on entry and exit.  Contact tracing information: All hospitality industry businesses (i.e. pubs, clubs, restaurants and cafés) in Queensland must comply with electronic contact information collection requirements.    This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423030856/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/victorias-restriction-levels-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419122032/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2024%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf     Victoria:   The Victorian Government COVID-19 Website states that ""From 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021, Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe Settings. ""  Some of the changes that apply to public events are:  ""Seated areas at indoor and outdoor entertainment, cultural and sporting venues can use 100% of their seated capacity up to a maximum of 1,000 patrons per space. The density quotient still applies at these venues in non-seated spaces e.g. bathrooms and lobbies.  These venues include theatres, cinemas, music halls, concert halls, auditoriums, galleries, museums, and sports and physical recreation facilities.  Non-seated venues will continue to be required to apply a density quotient of 1 per 2sqm, except unstaffed gyms(such as 24-hour gyms), which have a four-square metre rule.  Non seated venues (outdoor) do not have patron caps but density limits apply.  Non-seated venues (indoor) are capped at 75% capacity and density limits apply.  No cap on dance floors, but density limits apply, depending on the venue type.  Casinos to 75 per cent of venue capacity.  All venues must use the Government QR Code Service, or API linked digital system, to maintain electronic record keeping. ""    In addition, the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 19) effective from 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021 and current as of 19 April 2021, states in part that ""a person in the State of Victoria must not arrange  to meet, or organise or intentionally attend a gathering of, more than 199  other persons (with any infant under one year of age not counting towards  this limit) for a common purpose at a public place""  This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419130942/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202104/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20%28No%2019%29%20-%209%20April%202021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423031503/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live     New South Wales:   In a loosening of restrictions The Public Health (COVID-19 Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 was amended commencing 9 April 2021 and contains directions on gatherings, and the number of persons allowed on non-residential and residential premises.   In part, it states that ""Non-controlled outdoor public gatherings (up to 200): These events are restricted to 200 people (unless the gathering is a COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering with a COVID-19 Safety Plan.  COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering (up to 5,000): These events can have the lesser of 1 person per 2 square metres of space or 5,000 persons and do not need to be seated or enclosed by fencing and do not have a time limit. The organiser must have and comply with the relevant COVID-19 Safety Plan.  Controlled outdoor public gatherings (up to 10,000): A ticketed and seated COVID-19 safe outdoor gathering that does not last longer than 5 hours can have the maximum of the lesser of 1 person per 2 square metres of space or 10,000 persons. The event must be enclosed by fencing or another barrier. The organiser must have and comply with the relevant COVID-19 Safety Plan.""  This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423031623/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx

Snap lockdown - ""People in the Perth and Peel regions will not be able to leave home for the next three days except for essential reasons, including work where it is not possible to work from home, shopping for essentials, and exercise with a maximum of four people for an hour.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community    http://web.archive.org/web/20210425132208/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

The Western Australian government announced that people in Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must enter into a lockdown from 12.01am Saturday, April 24, to limit any potential spread of COVID-19. The lock-down was announced in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The lock-down announced was planned for 3 days, and is scheduled to end at 12.01am Tuesday, April 27.    STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST) DIRECTIONS were in force for the duration of the lockdown.  All public events were required to be cancelled.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502061717/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/20210423-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.    Restrictions for public gathering in place during this period are:   20-person limit for private indoor and outdoor gatherings  20-patron capacity limit and 4sqm rule for:  cafes, restaurants, bars and pubs for seated food and drink service only  public venues such as recreation centres, outdoor playgrounds, museums and swimming pools  places of worship  entertainment venues    Major Stadiums must be closed to the public.   These restrictions were enforced by the SAFE TRANSITION FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA DIRECTIONS (NO 2) These directions come into effect at 12.01 am on Tuesday, 27 April 2021.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502074436/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Safe-transition-for%20Western-Australia-Directions-No2.pdf

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    Outdoor gatherings can take place with up to 500 people without a COVID event plan  Seated hospitality venues, including restaurants, cafés, food courts and bars that provide seated service only, can open at 75 per cent capacity or apply the 2sqm rule – whichever is greater  Public venues, including, community centres, libraries, museums, galleries, recreation centres, can open with the 2sqm rule in place.    It was initially announced that during this period Major stadiums, including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena and HBF Park can operate at 75 per cent capacity; and that casinos and night clubs could open with square meter restrictions.  However, subsequently on the 2nd May at 11:35am the Additional Measures (Closure of Certain Premises) Directions were enacted.  These directions require all WA major stadiums, the casinos and nightclubs to close until 12:01am on 8 May 2021, provided that the West Coast Eagles v Fremantle match on 2 May 2021 may proceed without crowds.    The change came after a quarantine hotel security guard and two of his close contacts tested positive to COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084012/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/Additional-Measures-Closure-of-Certain-Premises-Directions.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084305/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-05-02/no-crowds-at-perth-stadium-for-western-derby/100110712

Note updated on the 17th May 2021 to address some typos included in the original note.  No substantive changes made.     Some Australian state/territory jurisdictions continue to impose capacity and square meter restrictions on public events.  However, not every Australian state and territory continues to impose capacity and square meter restrictions.  All jurisdictions require that contact tracing information be collected.  Coded as a 1T  Western Australia is a jurisdiction that currently maintains capacity and square meter restrictions on public gatherings.  The Northern Territory is a jurisdiction that does not currently have square meter or capacity restrictions on public gatherings.    Western Australia  As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    Events with over 500 people subject to 2sqm rule up to a maximum of 10,000 people and are required to have an approved COVID Event Plan  Seated hospitality venues, including restaurants, cafes, food courts and bars that provide seated service only can open at 75 per cent capacity or apply the 2sqm rule – whichever is greater  2sqm rule applies to all other unseated hospitality venues, except nightclubs  Gyms, fitness centres, dance studios, beauty salons and hairdressers can open with the 2sqm rule in place  Public venues, including community centres, libraries, museums, galleries and recreation centres can open with the 2sqm rule  Certain indoor and outdoor entertainment venues with fixed seating (theatres, cinemas, concert halls, comedy lounges and performing arts centres) can operate at 100 per cent capacity  Places of worship can operate at 100 per cent capacity    This is up to date as of the 7th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507114523/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do     The Northern Territory  According to the Northern Territory Government COVID-19 website, public events with more than 500 people must have an approved COVID safe plan.  The COVID safe plan includes collecting contact tracing information, consideration to encouraging social distancing, and consideration to cleaning and providing sanitation facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210507115147/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/business/guidelines-for-events-and-gatherings

Western Australia  On the 6th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing ""The easing of restrictions for Perth and Peel will proceed as planned from 12.01am Saturday, May 8. Following three COVID-19 cases detected in Perth over the weekend, the Chief Health Officer has advised Perth and Peel will need to see through the full 14-day incubation period, from the last case detected, which ends 12.01am Saturday, May 15, 2021.""  In part this announcement represented a modest loosening of restrictions around public gatherings and events. “  “The casino gaming floor can reopen subject to the two square metre rule;  Nightclubs can open subject to the two square metre rule;  100-person limit in all homes, for private indoor or outdoor gatherings;  Major stadiums, including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena and HBF Park can operate at 75 per cent capacity, with masks mandatory.  “  At this time the GATHERINGS AND ACTIVITIES DIRECTIONS (NO 2) further stipulated that for all of Western Australia (including the Perth and Peel Region) hospitality venues are able to operate at 75% capacity.   https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/070521-Safe-Transition-for-Western-Australia-Directions-No4.pdf   http://web.archive.org/web/20210517111820/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Restrictions-set-to-significantly-ease-from-12-01am-Saturday-May-8.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507110252/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/090421-Gathering-and-Activities-Directions-No2.pdf   Maintain T1 code.

Western Australia:  On the 13th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing "" From 12.01am Saturday, May 15, Perth and Peel will return to pre-lockdown life.""  The Western Australian COVID-19 Government Website further states that “There will be no capacity limits for weddings and funerals;  Major stadiums including Optus Stadium, RAC Arena, HBF Park and HBF Stadium – main arena can operate at 100 per cent capacity;  Visitor limits for patients in hospital, aged care or disability facilities will be lifted;”  However, also according to the Western Australian COVID-19 government website, some modest capacity restrictions do remain in place for some workplaces.  This includes the 2 square meter rule for the following venues: Nightclubs; Unseated bars; Unseated events/festivals (music, beer, wine, cultural etc.); Galleries; Museums; Libraries; Sport and recreation facilities including gyms, recreation centres, group fitness classes and indoor and outdoor swimming pools; Amusement parks; Wildlife parks and Perth Zoo; Function centres; Community, recreation or youth centres or facilities, including but not limited to community halls, sporting clubs, Returned and Services League facilities, and Police and Community Youth Centres; Adult entertainment premises, including but not limited to strip clubs, brothels and sex on premises venues; Casino and gambling venues; Arcades; Funeral parlours; Events that involve unfixed seating (e.g. BYO chair concerts).    The following hospitality venues are subject to a 75% capacity rule: Restaurants; Hotels (excluding bottleshops); Cafes; Food courts; Bars with seated service only.  Further WA’s major venues (Optus Stadium, RAC Arena, HBF Stadium – Main Arena, HBF Park) and   Indoor and outdoor fixed seating entertainment spaces including: auditoriums and amphitheatres; theatres; concert halls; cinemas; comedy lounges; performing arts centres; - are all 100% capacity (with no square meter rule).    Decided that WA does not meet criteria to be coded at a 1 for C3 as primary public event venues are at 100% capacity.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210517121029/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Pre-lockdown-life-to-resume-in-full-from-12-01am-this-Saturday.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517121130/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/pre-lockdown-life-resumes-perth-and-peel-regions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517124028/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do    No other Australian States or Territories have percentage capacity rules for public event venues.  The norm is to operate at a one person per two squared meter rule).  South Australia has a 3 people per 4 square meter rule.  Decided, according to the interpretation guide, this does not reach threshold for a 1 code under C3.   Therefore code changed to a 0.     NSW:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521012333/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/square-metres-rules   ACT:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521100822/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/what-you-can-do/what-you-can-do   NT:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521100906/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/business-and-work/business   SA:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521101101/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/restrictions-and-responsibilities/activities-and-gatherings   TAS:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521101132/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/keeping-yourself-safe/gatherings-density-and-physical-distancing   QLD:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210521101227/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/roadmap-to-easing-queenslands-restrictions

While many states have density restrictions in place for event venues, the only state with a percentage capacity restriction (which could be counted as a 1 in this scale) in place is WA (see C2), however restaurants, bars etc. probably fall into C2 rather than C3. Events venues like theatres, cinemas, comedy clubs, sports grounds are all operating at 100% capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517124028/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do    WA and every other jurisdiction bar NT has density restrictions (1 person per 2sqm) in place, however, these do not fall within the definition of a 1 on this variable in the coding guide.

As of May 25, community transmission in Victoria led to to new restrictions. However, restrictions on public events have not yet been specified. The Victorian Public Health Advisory Panel will make a decision in the coming days on whether new restrictions are needed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525010125if_/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/additional-covidsafe-measures-keep-victorians-safe

Queensland:   In a loosening of restrictions The Restrictions for Queensland Direction (No. 2) was revoked from 6:00am on 15 April 2021.  The Movement and Gathering Direction (No. 9) are effective from: 6am AEST 15 April 2021 and remain current as of 19th April 2021.  In part these directions limit the gatherings of up to 100 persons at a residence.   This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104947/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-for-queensland-2  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419130528/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/movement-gathering-direction     Victoria:   In a modest loosening of restrictions the Stay Safe Directions (Victoria) (No 19) came into effect at 11:59:00pm on 9 April 2021 and remain current as of 19 April 2021.   In part this direction states that no more that “no more than 99 other persons who are visiting for a social gathering; “are permitted to enter a residence at which they do not ordinarily reside.    This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032200/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/movement-gathering-direction  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032234/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/revoked/restrictions-for-queensland-2     These are currently the most stringent COVID-19 related policy restrictions around private gatherings in Australia.

Each Australian State and Territory has some level of additional policies or recommendations for the use of public transport.   Below is current policy/advice as on the 23rd April 2021 for some states.     New South Wales:   The NSW government NSW transport website COVID-19: Safer travel guidance states that “More than 1,200 extra weekly services will be added to the 3,300 extra services already running across the network to help customers stay COVID safe and enjoy all the city and surrounds has to offer. These extra services will help you continue to make smart travel choices. All extra services continue to run..”     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032509/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-what-you-can-do  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032624/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance     Queensland:   The Queensland Government Public Transport website states that additional peak hour train and bus services, in response to COVID-19 continue.  Additional bus services have been extended until 25 June 2021, All additional train services introduced in will become permanent.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423032943/https://translink.com.au/updates/14696   web.archive.org/web/20210423033135/https://translink.com.au/travel-with-us/covid-19/pt-plan    Western Australia:   The WA Government Public Transport Authority Website states that “The PTA is closely monitoring what is happening with coronavirus (COVID-19) and is increasing the cleaning regime on all the vehicles in our Transperth, Transwa, TransRegional and School Bus Services road and rail fleets.”  No evidence of COVID-19 policies resulting in or significantly reduce volume/route/means of transport available.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423033346/https://www.pta.wa.gov.au/

COVID has changed the way public transport operates in all states. In two states, these policies would be classified as a 1 under the interpretation that an increase in services in order to decrease the density of passengers counts as a 1.  Victoria: Victoria is encouraging travel outside of peak times by discounting fares in order to reduce the density of passengers. https://web.archive.org/web/20210521014823/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/more-choices-victorian-train-passengers  NSW: NSW has capacity restrictions of 75% on all public transport. This is a relaxation of earlier policies from 19 April 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521015031/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance

Snap lockdown - ""People in the Perth and Peel regions will not be able to leave home for the next three days except for essential reasons, including work where it is not possible to work from home, shopping for essentials, and exercise with a maximum of four people for an hour.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community

The Western Australian government announced that people in Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must enter into a lockdown from 12.01am Saturday, April 24, to limit any potential spread of COVID-19. The lock-down was announced in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The lock-down announced was planned for 3 days, and is scheduled to end at 12.01am Tuesday, April 27.    STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST) DIRECTIONS were in force for the duration of the lockdown and stipulated that individuals could leave their home for the following reasons:   work because you cannot work from home if your place of work is not closed  shop for essentials like groceries, medicine and necessary supplies  access medical or health care  provide care and support to a relative or other person who has particular needs  other specifically authorised compassionate requirements  exercise, but only for 1 hour per day. You can exercise with a maximum of 4 other people , as long as there’s no more than 2 adults at one time  leave due to an emergency.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502061717/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/20210423-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.  No stay at home orders remain in place; either in WA or any other Australian jurisdiction.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel

There were no stay-at-home requirements in Australia during this period. The last stay-at-home order was in Perth and Peel in WA which ended on 27 April 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel

T1 code reflects Western Australia continuing intra state travel restrictions.        New South Wales:   As documented on the NSW Government COVID-19 Website on the 12th April 2021l five local government areas (forming a part of Brisbane city QLD) were considered Affected Areas.  This remains up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.  Individuals traveling from Affected Areas are allow to enter NSW.  They must complete the declaration form either 24 hours before entry to NSW or on entry.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210423035934/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423040253/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/interstate-hotspots     Victoria:   According to the VIC Government COVID-19 Website  “Based on an assessment of public health risks, the Chief Health Officer has declared the following areas will be designated green zones under Victoria’s ‘traffic light’ travel permit system effective 11:59pm, 11 April 2021:  Greater Brisbane (City of Brisbane, City of Ipswich, Logan City, Moreton Bay Region, Redlands City)   The Gladstone region in Queensland   Byron Shire in New South Wales”    This is up to date on the 23rd April 2021. There are no VIC Govt declared Orange or Red zones and therefore no inter or intra state travel restrictions.    web.archive.org/web/20210423040908/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system    Queensland:   According to the VIC Government COVID-19 Website restrictions eased for all of QLD from 6am Thursday 15 April 2021.  Since this time there has been no intrastate or interstate travel restrictions in place.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210423040919/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/border-closing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041041/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19     Western Australia:   In an easing of restrictions, and according to the Western Australian COVID-19 Government website, Queensland transitioned from a ‘Low risk’ state to a ‘Very low risk’ state from 12.01am April 19th 2020.  This is up to date as of the 23rd April 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041457/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/controlled-interstate-border-changes-queensland     Requirements for individuals entering WA from Very Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  If travelling by air, you must wear a mask on your flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS to exit the airport.  No quarantine required.”    Requirements for individuals entering WA from Low Risk jurisdictions are:   “Before travelling to WA, complete a mandatory G2G PASS registration and declaration.  Complete a health screening on arrival.  Scan your G2G PASS and then verify you have suitable premises for self-quarantine.  If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days.  You must wear a mask from when you enter WA until you arrive at suitable self-quarantine premises or government approved quarantine facilities. In addition if travelling by air, you must also wear a mask on the flight while in WA airspace, and while inside the airport (with some exceptions – e.g. children under the age of 12 are not required to wear a mask).  You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041556/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-border     However, WA continues to implement policies restricting intrastate movement.  The WA Government COVID-19 website states:  There are more than 200 remote Aboriginal communities who are more vulnerable to COVID-19 than other Western Australians.  To help keep the communities safe from COVID-19, there are strict travel restrictions in place.”   Under the WA Government’s Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  providing essential services and supplies  going to work or school there  entering for family or cultural reasons  delivering a community program or activity  entering in an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423041734/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel   http://web.archive.org/web/20210420072233/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do     Tasmania:   From the 13th April 2021 and current up to 23rd April 2021, the Tasmanian COVID-19 Government Website shows that there are no inter state travel restrictions issued.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423042005/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania     Northern Territory:   According to the Norther Territory COVID-19 website there are no currently declared hotspots, which is up to date as of 23rd April 2021.  There most recently declared NT Govt declared hotspot ended on 3:00pm on 1 April 2021.  Therefore there has been not intra or interstate travel restrictions since 1st April 2021 and current as of 23rd April 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423043701/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423043857/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19/former-declared-hotspots    There are currently no COVID-19 specific intra state travel restrictions within the NT.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423044526/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/remote-work-and-travel   Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory Government website states on the 23rd of April 2021 that there is currently “no areas of concern”.  This has been the policy of the ACT Government since 1pm on 1st April 2021, when all travel restrictions on travellers from the Greater Brisbane Area were lifted.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210423044602/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/updates/covid-19-areas-of-concern   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423044840/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/news-articles/act-travel-restrictions-reduced-for-greater-brisbane

Western Australia  As published on the Western Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.    Regional travel restrictions were removed – that previously restricted travel outside or into the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island areas.  However, restrictions on travel to remote Aboriginal communities remain in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel       Victoria   In response to instances of community transmission of COVID-19 in Western Australia (originating from the Hotel quarantine system) and as published on the Victorian Government’s COVID-19 website, “The Chief Health Officer has declared the Perth metropolitan area and Peel region in Western Australia red zones (other than for transit) under Victoria’s ‘traffic light’ travel permit system from 2:01am Victorian time on Saturday 24 April.”…” A red zone means non-Victorian residents are not allowed to enter Victoria without an exception, Specified Worker Permit, transit permit, freight worker permit, or exemption.” This policy change represented a significant tightening of restrictions.    This Victorian Government policy remained in force until 12.01am Wednesday 28 April.  Victoria’s Chief Health Officer had declared that the Perth metropolitan area and the Peel region in Western Australia would be designated orange zones under Victoria’s travel permit system from 12.01am Wednesday 28 April.   People entering Victoria with an orange zone permit must [self] isolate, get a coronavirus test within 72 hours, and stay isolated until they receive a negative result    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426065312/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507123858/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system

The Victorian Government Covid-19 website states that   “Victoria’s Chief Health Officer has declared that the Perth metropolitan area and the Peel region in Western Australia will be designated orange zones under Victoria’s travel permit system from 12.01am Wednesday 28 April.   People entering Victoria with an orange zone permit must [self] isolate, get a coronavirus test within 72 hours, and stay isolated until they receive a negative result. ”  This up to date as of the 7th May 2021.   This policy represents an easing of restrictions.  Previously, Perth metropolitan area and the Peel region in Western Australia were considered Red zones by the Victorian Government.  A red zone means non-Victorian residents are not allowed to enter Victoria without an exception, Specified Worker Permit, transit permit, freight worker permit, or exemption.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507123858/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system

*Updated note on 21/05/2021 to fix typo. No substantive change made.     Coded a 1T in recognition of the COVID-19 related intra state restrictions in place limiting travel to Remote Aboriginal Communities in Western Australia, with exceptions for providing essential services and supplies; going to work or school there; entering for family or cultural reasons; delivering a community program or activity; entering in an emergency.  No other jurisdictions have policy in place that meets threshold for coding at C7.       Victoria  The Victorian Government Covid-19 website states that   “The Chief Health Officer has declared that the Perth metropolitan area and the Peel region in Western Australia will be designated green zones under Victoria’s ‘traffic light’ travel permit system, effective 11:59pm, 10 May 2021.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507123858/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system    New South Wales:   As published on The New South Wales COVID-19 Government website, the NSW Government has issued a “A COVID-19 concerns notice has been issued for Greater Melbourne local government areas. Follow the rules for interstate travellers.” This applies to individuals “entering NSW on or after 6am Wednesday 12 May who has been in Greater Melbourne in the previous 14 days”.  It requires anyone who has entered of plans to enter NSW from Greater Melbourne to complete a “NSW entry declaration form” only.  However, the NSW Government has further identified places of high concern with Greater Melbourne.  These are specific venues on particular dates and times.  People who have entered NSW after visiting a place of high concern within the last 14 days must self-isolate until it has been 14 days since they visited the place of high concern.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517135301/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/interstate-hotspots   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517135104/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf     Queensland:   According to the Queensland Government COVID-19 website states that “You can enter Queensland from any Australian state or territory. There are no COVID-19 hotspots in Australia.    The Queensland Declared Hotspots Direction shows that there have been no hotspots declared by the Queensland Government since 27th April 2021.   The Queensland Border Declaration Pass system is not active. You do not need a border pass to enter Queensland.”  There are current contact tracing alerts and requirements to quarantine or self-isolate if you have visited specific venues at specific times in NSW and VIC.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517132159/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/contact-tracing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517132704/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/government-actions/border-closing  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507122910/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/declared-hotspots-direction     Western Australia:   The Western Australian Government COVID-19 website shows that since the 5th May 2021 and current at 17th May 2021 all Australian stated and territories have been considered “very low risk”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517140903/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-border   However, as also published on the Western Australian Government COVID-19 website and enforced by the Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions (No. 3) there remains travel restrictions in place to protect residents of Remote Aboriginal Communities in WA.    “Under the WA Government’s Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  providing essential services and supplies  going to work or school there  entering for family or cultural reasons  delivering a community program or activity  entering in an emergency.  These people cannot enter a community if they have COVID-19 or symptoms of COVID-19, or if they are waiting for a test result or have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517141218/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517141440/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-08/Remote%20Aboriginal%20Communities%20Directions%20%28No.%203%29.pdf     Tasmania:   As published on the Tasmanian government’s COVID-19 website, all Australian stated and territories are considered ‘low risk’.  However, there are some specific travel alerts for high-risk premises (at specific times and dates) in NSW and VIC.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517140344/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517140729/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert     Northern Territory:   The Northern Territory COVID-19 Government website shows that there have been no Norther Territory declared hotspots since 2.30 pm on 27 April 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517133101/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19/former-declared-hotspots     Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory considered some specific venues (at specific times and dates) in NSW and Victoria to be place of concern.  “Persons who have been to a COVID-19 place of concern in the specified timeframe must follow the public health guidance outlined in the COVID-19 Area of Concern Notice. This may require a person to take a specific action such as get tested for COVID-19 and isolate until receiving a negative result, or to monitor for symptoms. The specific actions may differ if you are identified as a casual contact or a close contact.”  However, the Australian Capital Territory does not have any currently identified areas of concern.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517133609/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/1748417/COVID-19-Areas-of-Concern-notice_17-May-2021-No-40.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517133734/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/updates/covid-19-areas-of-concern

***Recoded from 2T to 1T.     Previous coding note:   NT has had in place mandatory quarantine for those who have visited exposure sites in Victoria and SA that have been active since May 17.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521020359/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19  Tasmania has barred travel by those who have been at an exposure site in Victoria within the past 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521020444/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert  Queensland has implemented mandatory quarantine for those who have been to a Victorian exposure site.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521020611/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/contact-tracing

After community transmission in Victoria, all other jurisdictions have introduced some kind of restriction on those who have visited the exposure sites identified by Victorian contact tracers. This has not extended to a ban on travel from Victoria or Greater Melbourne though so far. Those who have been to exposure sites must quarantine and in the case of Tasmania they will be flat out banned from entering the state.    This media link summarises the immediate responses by states.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525011014/https://www.9news.com.au/national/coronavirus-how-states-and-territories-are-reacting-to-victorias-new-covid19-cases-nsw-queensland-sa-wa-nt-tasmania-travel-quarantine-restrictions/82272f87-e551-41a8-93cd-54af29b564b9

As published on the Australian Government Home affairs website, “quarantine free travel between Australia and New Zealand will commence at 21:59 AEST on 18 April 2021. All travellers who have been in either Australia or New Zealand for 14 days can travel by air between Australia and New Zealand quarantine free, without the need to apply for a travel exemption. This includes travellers who have spent all 14 days in either safe travel zone country, or people who have travelled between the two countries and are returning within the 14 day period.” Previously individuals could travel from New Zealand to Australia quarantine free BUT individuals from Australia could not travel to New Zealand Quarantine free.  This policy change represents a modest loosening of border restrictions.    However, other than quarantine-free flights from New Zealand, Australia's boarders are closed to non-citizens (with very limited exception).  As such, continuing to code as a 4.   This is up to date on the 23rd April 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423034950/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423035333/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/new-zealand-safe-travel-zone

According to the Australian Commonwealth Australian Government COVID-19 website on the 28th March 2021:   “Australia has strict border measures in place to protect the health of the Australian community. Very limited flights are currently available to and from Australia and you may not be able to travel at this time. Travel restrictions are subject to change. Check back regularly. See: National Cabinet media statement.  You cannot come to Australia unless you are in an exempt category or you have been granted an individual exemption.  If you are not in an exempt category you can request an individual exemption to Australia's travel restrictions.  Temporary visa holders  Temporary visa holders in Australia can depart Australia at any time, however, they will generally not be permitted to return. More information can be found at Temporary visa holders leaving Australia for a short trip overseas.  Exempt categories  You are automatically exempt from the travel restrictions and can enter Australia (without obtaining an individual exemption) if you are:  •	an Australian citizen  •	a permanent resident of Australia  •	an immediate family member of an Australian citizen or permanent resident*  •	a New Zealand citizen usually resident in Australia and their immediate family members  •	a person who has been in New Zealand or Australia for 14 days or more immediately prior to arrival by air in Australia  •	a diplomat accredited to Australia, including their immediate family members (each member of the family unit must hold a valid subclass 995 visa)  •	a person transiting Australia for 72 hours or less  •	airline crew, maritime crew including marine pilots  •	a person recruited under the Government approved Seasonal Worker Program or Pacific Labour Scheme  •	a person who holds a Business Innovation and Investment (subclass 188) visa.  * If you hold a temporary visa or do not yet hold a valid visa for Australia, you must provide proof of your relationship (such as your marriage certificate, evidence of your de-facto relationship such as shared finances or property, your birth certificate or birth certificate for your children) to the Department before you travel to Australia. Do not travel until we advise that you can. You can find out more about how to provide this information at Immediate family of Australian citizens or permanent residents or New Zealand citizens usually resident in Australia.  You need to carry evidence that you meet one of the above categories when travelling. Additional evidence may be requested.  If you are not in an exempt category you can request an individual exemption to Australia's travel restrictions.  ”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210428235543/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

Australia has had in place very restrictive border policies since the beginning of the crisis. The only people who may travel to Australia are citizens, permanent residents or their immediate family members. In these cases there is mandatory 14 day hotel quarantine. The one exception both these rules is travel from New Zealand which is governed as if it is domestic travel (i.e. it is the role of the states to regulate travel unless the federal government chooses to abolish its travel bubble agreement).  Previously, travel from India was banned even for classes of people otherwise allowed to return. However, since May 15, returns from India have been allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521023454/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

However, since May 15, returns from India have been allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521023454/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

Up to date as of the 26th April 2021 there continues to be no nationwide income support available in response to COVID-19. Updated archived URLS provided.       According to the Australian Government Services Australia website, the ""JobKeeper Payment stopped 28 March 2021."" and ""The temporary Coronavirus Supplement, at a rate of $150 per fortnight, ended on 31 March 2021."" ""working age payments increase by $50 per fortnight the income free area for certain income support payments, including JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance for job seekers, changes to $150 per fortnight""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505044235/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-get-payment/im-job-seeker https://web.archive.org/web/20210505044343/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-need-payment  https://web.archive.org/web/20210505044429/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/jobkeeper-payment-ends-28-march-2021

Since the abolition of the JobKeeper program on 28 March, Australia has not had an income support policy in place. This kind of relief would generally be the purview of the federal government and no states have had income support policies of their own during the pandemic either.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521024323/https://www.ato.gov.au/general/jobkeeper-payment/

Australia’s financial relief programs (governed primarily by the states) are no longer in effect since Victoria, NSW and WA removed their eviction moratorium programs in March 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521024522/https://www.sbs.com.au/news/a-wave-of-homelessness-could-be-about-to-hit-australia-as-rules-preventing-evictions-end  Changes to tenancies were the main government-enforced contract relief as government-encouraged load relief was implemented by banks.

Australia’s states have controlled testing, however there has been a largely unform policy since the beginning of the pandemic that anyone with symptoms can be tested with some nuances that differ between states (though practically all would be a 2 on this scale). Asymptomatic testing has not been encouraged outside of meeting asymptomatic testing obligations like for hotel quarantine workers or close contacts of confirmed cases. States have been in control of contact tracing with some assistance from the federal government. It is difficult to know what the capacity of states to contact trace has been as there have been few community cases in Australia recently. However, the fact that states have been able to tamp down those few outbreaks quite quickly. States have centralised check-in apps to their own systems and in most states contact tracing is now mandatory in venues.  A review of Australia’s contact tracing capabilities in November 2020 found that while there is room for improvement, the capabilities of Australia’s contact tracing system have greatly improved since the start of the pandemic. Events since the release of that report have given no reason to doubt that we have comprehensive capabilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210416224611/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/national-contact-tracing-review-national-contact-tracing-review.pdf
