The Western Australian government brought the FACE COVERING DIRECTIONS (NO 2) into force at 6pm Friday 23rd April 2021.  This was done in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The Face Covering Directions (No2.) Stipulate that those in Metropolitan Perth, the Peel Region, and Rottnest Island must wear a face covering at all times while they are outside the place where they ordinarily reside, including while in a vehicle (with some limited exceptions).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502071435/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Face-Covering-Directions-No2.pdf

""Perth and Peel entered a snap three-day lockdown from midnight Friday after a Victorian man, who tested positive to Covid-19, spent five days in the community while infectious after leaving hotel quarantine."" ... ""Masks must be worn from 6pm Friday until midnight on Monday night, except during “vigorous” exercise or while at home or in a vehicle.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.      The SAFE TRANSITION FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA DIRECTIONS (NO 2) These directions come into effect at 12.01 am on Tuesday, 27 April 2021.    This direction maintained the previous mask wearing requirements for Metropolitan Perth, the Peel Region, and Rottnest Island.  Individuals must wear a face covering at all times while they are outside the place where they ordinarily reside, including while in a vehicle (with some limited exceptions).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502074436/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Safe-transition-for%20Western-Australia-Directions-No2.pdf

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    Face Covering Directions (No 3) came into effect at 12.01 am on Saturday, 1 May 2021.    They stipulate that those in Perth, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must (with some exceptions) wear a mask:   (a) in an indoor space that is not in a private home;  (b) on public transport (including, for the avoidance of doubt, a bus, ferry, train,  taxi or rideshare vehicle);  ( c) in an outdoor space where it is not possible to physically distance;  ( d) in a residential aged care facility if the person is a quarantine centre worker;  ( e) . in a private home while a wedding, wedding reception, funeral or wake is being  held at the private home and more than 30 persons are present in the private  home; or in ( or in the process of entering or leaving) a major stadium.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further   http://web.archive.org/web/20210502090558/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Face-Covering-Directions-No3_0.pdf

NOTE UPDATED ON 17th May as previously provided note included an incorrect archived URL (was archived for the incorrect legal direction).     New South Wales:   The NSW Premier released a media statement on the 6th May 2010 announcing the introduction of new restrictions for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains.  This announcement was in response to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.   In part the NSW Government COVID-19 website states “The following measures will be effective from midday today, 6 May 2021 (enforceable from 5pm) until 12:01am Monday, 10 May for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains)”  “A face mask (fitted face covering) is mandatory in the following indoor settings:  •	shopping (retail, supermarkets and shopping centres)  •	public and community transport  •	indoor areas of NSW airports, including passenger waiting areas   •	during a flight, when the plane is    o	landing at or taking off from the airport or   o	flying in NSW airspace.   •	indoor entertainment (including cinemas and theatres)  •	places of public worship (unless you are a person who is integral to the conduct of the religious service and are singing or chanting)  •	hair and beauty premises  •	tattoo parlours  •	massage parlours  •	betting agencies  •	gaming areas in licensed premises  •	visiting residential aged care facilities.  Face masks are also mandatory for all staff in  •	hospitality venues (for staff who have a customer-facing role).  Patrons at hospitality venues and kiosks do not need to wear a face mask (unless you are in an area of the venue used primarily for gaming, including a gaming lounge).”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507095539/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507100126/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/covid-19-restrictions-update-6-may     Western Australia  Face Covering Directions (No 3) came into effect at 12.01 am on Saturday, 1 May 2021 and remains current as of the 7th May 2021.   This direction stipulates that those in Perth, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must (with some exceptions) wear a mask:   (a) in an indoor space that is not in a private home;  (b) on public transport (including, for the avoidance of doubt, a bus, ferry, train,  taxi or rideshare vehicle);  ( c) in an outdoor space where it is not possible to physically distance;  ( d) in a residential aged care facility if the person is a quarantine centre worker;  ( e) . in a private home while a wedding, wedding reception, funeral or wake is being  held at the private home and more than 30 persons are present in the private  home; or in ( or in the process of entering or leaving) a major stadium.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210502090558/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Face-Covering-Directions-No3_0.pdf    Therefore maintain the 3T code.

Western Australia:  On the 6th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing ""The easing of restrictions for Perth and Peel will proceed as planned from 12.01am Saturday, May 8. Following three COVID-19 cases detected in Perth over the weekend, the Chief Health Officer has advised Perth and Peel will need to see through the full 14-day incubation period, from the last case detected, which ends 12.01am Saturday, May 15, 2021.""  In part, this announcement included the relaxation of mask wearing requirements.  ""The following transitional restrictions are set to take effect from 12.01am Saturday, May 8:  Masks are not required except on public transport, in hospitals, aged care and disabilities facilities, and at stadiums or events with more than 1,000 people""  Western Australia's mask wearing policy no longer meets requirements for a 3 code and instead meets requirement for a 2 code.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517111820/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Restrictions-set-to-significantly-ease-from-12-01am-Saturday-May-8.aspx    New South Wales:   The NSW Premier released a media statement on the 6th May 2021 announcing the introduction of new restrictions for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains.  This announcement was in response to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.   In part the NSW Government COVID-19 website states “The following measures will be effective from midday today, 6 May 2021 (enforceable from 5pm) until 12:01am Monday, 10 May for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains)”  “A face mask (fitted face covering) is mandatory in the following indoor settings:  •	shopping (retail, supermarkets and shopping centres)  •	public and community transport  •	indoor areas of NSW airports, including passenger waiting areas   •	during a flight, when the plane is    o	landing at or taking off from the airport or   o	flying in NSW airspace.   •	indoor entertainment (including cinemas and theatres)  •	places of public worship (unless you are a person who is integral to the conduct of the religious service and are singing or chanting)  •	hair and beauty premises  •	tattoo parlours  •	massage parlours  •	betting agencies  •	gaming areas in licensed premises  •	visiting residential aged care facilities.  Face masks are also mandatory for all staff in  •	hospitality venues (for staff who have a customer-facing role).  Patrons at hospitality venues and kiosks do not need to wear a face mask (unless you are in an area of the venue used primarily for gaming, including a gaming lounge).”  This remained up to date on the 8th of May 2021.  As facemasks are not required in ALL public places (for example patrons of hospitality venues are not required to wear masks) New South Wales does not reach threshold to be coded at 3 level.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210507095539/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/greater-sydney  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507100126/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/covid-19-restrictions-update-6-may    New South Wales and Western Australia currently have the most stringent policies regarding mask wearing.  However, every other Australian state and territory also mandates the wearing of facemasks at airports and on domestic flights (at a minimum).  Therefore, a 2G code is given. Western Australia:  On the 6th of May 2021, Mark McGowan premier of Western Australia released a press statement announcing ""The easing of restrictions for Perth and Peel will proceed as planned from 12.01am Saturday, May 8. Following three COVID-19 cases detected in Perth over the weekend, the Chief Health Officer has advised Perth and Peel will need to see through the full 14-day incubation period, from the last case detected, which ends 12.01am Saturday, May 15, 2021.""  In part, this announcement included the relaxation of mask wearing requirements.  ""The following transitional restrictions are set to take effect from 12.01am Saturday, May 8:  Masks are not required except on public transport, in hospitals, aged care and disabilities facilities, and at stadiums or events with more than 1,000 people""  Western Australia's mask wearing policy no longer meets requirements for a 3 code and instead meets requirement for a 2 code.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517111820/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/05/Restrictions-set-to-significantly-ease-from-12-01am-Saturday-May-8.aspx     New South Wales:   On the 9th May 2021 the new South Wales Government published a COVID-19 update on the NSW Government website.  This announcement represented a modest relaxation of the mask wearing rules in NSW.  “To safeguard the community and reduce the risk of further transmission, the NSW Government has extended by one week the temporary COVID-safe measures (except for one change in regard to retail) which were initially put in place until 12:01am Monday 10 May for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains).  The one change to the existing orders removes the requirement for retail customers to wear masks, however public-facing staff in retail outlets must continue to do so.  The following measures will now be in effect until 12:01 am Monday 17 May.  Visitors to households are limited to 20 guests, including children.  Masks are compulsory on public transport and in public indoor venues such as theatres and gaming areas. Masks should also be worn in hospitals, and aged care facilities.  Masks are not required in gyms or other similar facilities like indoor pools or dance studios.”  NSW meets the requirement for a 2 code.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517112850/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20210509_00.aspx     New South Wales and Western Australia currently have the most stringent policies regarding mask wearing.  However, every other Australian state and territory also mandates the wearing of facemasks at airports and on domestic flights (at a minimum).  Therefore, a 2G code is given.   Updated archived links are provided below to sources for the remaining Australian states and territories to their mask wearing requirements. The most stringent jurisdiction in Australia for masks was previously Greater Sydney in NSW where masks were mandatory on public transport and for customer-facing staff until May 17 as part of a ramp up of restrictions in response to community transmission of COVID from a man in hotel quarantine to a couple in Sydney through a hypothesised missing link case. NSW has now returned to its previous restriction settings across the state.  Masks remain mandatory in all Australian airports under an agreement between states which therefore corresponds to a coding of 2G.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521055709/https://www.infrastructure.gov.au/aviation/domestic-passenger-journey-protocol.aspx

After community transmission occurred in Victoria, new masking rules were introduced there on May 25 which makes wearing a mask mandatory in all indoor settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525010125if_/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/additional-covidsafe-measures-keep-victorians-safe    Masking is still mandatory in all Australian airports per the decision of national cabinet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521055709/https://www.infrastructure.gov.au/aviation/domestic-passenger-journey-protocol.aspx    Even though the Victorian policy is vastly more stringent than the airport policy elsewhere in Australia, the fact that masking outdoors is not required means that both policies fall under a 2 and so this has been coded as 2G.

5th May 2021 this code was changed from a 3G to a 4G.  This change was made in recognition that in addition to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), and Elderly groups - Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55 were also able to access the vaccine.    A press statement on the 22nd April from the Australian Prime Minister announced some changes to Australia’s Vaccination program.    “National Cabinet agreed the imperative to work together to administer COVID-19 vaccinations to Australians as quickly as possible.  National Cabinet agreed to recalibrate the delivery model for the COVID-19 Vaccination Rollout Strategy, taking into account the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) medical advice on the use of AstraZeneca vaccines, and COVID-19 vaccine supply arrangements, by:    Limiting access to the Pfizer vaccine to:  People aged under 50 years eligible in phases 1a and 1b (pending commencement of subsequent phases);  Residential Aged Care Facility (RACF) residents (through completion of the Commonwealth’s existing in-reach program):  Disability care residents with complex needs who require in-reach vaccination services;  People in remote and very remote communities where it makes sense to use a single vaccine for all or most of the community; and  In very limited circumstances, quarantine, border and frontline health care workers who are 50 years of age or over and not already vaccinated, where the relevant state or territory determines the worker should be fully vaccinated and protected as soon as possible.    Better utilising the available stock of AstraZeneca doses: by bringing forward access to the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine for phase 2a eligible people aged 50–69 years commencing with General Practice Respiratory Clinics (GPRCs) and state and territory COVID-19 vaccination sites from 3 May 2021 and General Practice (GP) clinics from 17 May 2021. Individual GP clinics who have the capacity to and wish to commence earlier than 17 May can apply to the Department of Health for access to this cohort earlier.”    Australia remains at stages 1A and 1B of the Vaccine role out (full details at the link – these details remain the same as those provided in the qualitative note made on 18th April 2021).   AstraZenec and Pfizer vaccines are being used.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423073431/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/national-cabinet-4   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423073517/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine

5th May 2021 this code was changed from a 3G to a 4G.  This change was made in recognition that in addition to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), and Elderly groups - Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 505 were also able to access the vaccine.    According to the Australian Commonwealth Australian Government COVID-19 website on the 27th March 2021:   “We are currently vaccinating people in Phase 1a and Phase 1b. States and territories will begin vaccinating people in Phase 2a in May starting with all adults 50 years and over.”  ""Phase 1a   Quarantine and border workers, including:  •	staff at entry points to the country (such as sea ports and land borders)  •	staff working in quarantine facilities, including those employed under Commonwealth, state or private agreements, and    •	Commonwealth employees (including Defence personnel) who are identified as having the potential to encounter returning travellers as part of their work.  Quarantine, border and front line health care workers will need to provide proof of occupation to demonstrate their eligibility.	   Frontline health care worker sub-groups for prioritisation  •	frontline staff in facilities or services such as hospital emergency departments,COVID-19 and respiratory wards, Intensive Care Units and High-dependency Units  •	laboratory staff handling potentially infectious material  •	ambulance and paramedics service  •	GP respiratory clinics  •	COVID-19 testing facilities  Frontline health care workers who fit under one of these sub groups will need to provide proof of occupation to demonstrate their eligibility. 	   Aged care and disability care staff, including:  •	nursing and personal care staff  •	allied health professionals who routinely provide care  •	kitchen, cleaning, laundry, garden and office staff	   Aged care and disability care residents	    Phase 1b  Learn more about Phase 1b, including eligibility and evidence requirements    Healthcare workers currently employed and not included in Phase 1a	   Household contacts of quarantine and border workers	   Critical and high risk workers who are currently employed including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing	   Elderly people aged 80 years and over	   Elderly people aged 70 years and over	   Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 50 years and over	   Adults with an underlying medical condition or significant disability""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210427083649/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine

All Australian States and Territories, except for New South Wales have mandated narrow protections in place.  New South Wales residential aged care facilities must consider the advice of the Chief Health Office, but are able to make their own policy.  Therefore coded as a 2T.      New South Wales:   The NSW Health COVID-19 website states that “Public Health (COVID-19 Gathering Restrictions) Order 2021 commenced on 29 March 2021 (with amendments commencing 30 March 2021 and 9 April 2021) and contains directions on gatherings, and the number of persons allowed on non-residential and residential premises.”    “Residential aged care facilities: Operators of aged care facilities must consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in relation to:  management of visitors  screening of staff and visitors  arrangements for group recreation and other activities for residents  wearing of face masks by staff and visitors  vaccinations against influenza and COVID-19”  http://web.archive.org/web/20210423083322/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx     Victoria:   According to the Victorian Government COVID-19 website from 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021 Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe settings.  This changed remain current as of the 23rd April 2021.    Face masks?are mandatory when visiting people in?care facilities.   There are no limits on the purpose of visits, the number of visitors or the length of the visit to care facilities.  Facilities may have additional requirements, conditions or restrictions for entry.   You will not be permitted to enter a care facility if you are a worker or visitor and you:   are a diagnosed person or close contact under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions;   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, arrived in Australia from overseas (other than on a quarantine-free flight from an overseas location designated by the Australian Government as a green travel zone);   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, had known contact with a confirmed case (except in the course of your employment while wearing the appropriate level of personal protective equipment in the circumstances);    have SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms; or   if you are a visitor – have been tested for COVID-19 and are awaiting your test results.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423075712/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/visiting-care-facilities     Queensland: The QLD Aged Care Direction (No. 26) came into effect 3pm AEST 8 April 2021 and remain current as of the 23th April 2021.   Queensland COVID-19 Restricted Areas (No. 14) came into effect on 6am AEST 15 April 2021 and remains in effect as of the 23rd April 2021.  This direction declared that there are no Local Government Areas listed as Queensland COVID-19 restricted areas.    In combination these directions mean that residential aged care facilities can have visitors except in the following circumstance: a person has been outside of Australian within the last 14 days; visited a declare COVID-19 hotspot within the last 14 days; been in contact with a COVID-19 positive person within the last 14 days; have symptoms consistent with COVID-19; or is awaiting the results of a COVID-19 test.   There is no restriction on the number of visitors.  Physical distancing and limiting contact with other persons at the facility must be complied with to the extent practicable.   Residents are able to leave facilities for any purpose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423074236/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/queensland-covid-19-restricted-areas     Western Australia:   The VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES DIRECTIONS (NO 7) came into effect at 11.59 p.m. on 23rd February 2021 and remains in place as of the 23rd April 2021.    Visitors are allow to residential aged care facilities except where and individual:   returned from overseas in the last 14 days  been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days  a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory infection (e.g. cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  not had an up-to-date influenza vaccination.  Additionally, quarantine centre workers must wear a face mask and keep 1.5 metres away from other people when visiting residential aged care facilities  People entering residential aged care facilities to provide a service to a resident must only do so if it is not reasonably practicable reasonably practicable for the service to be provided via telehealth or some other adaptive model of care or for the resident to attend an external facility to receive the service.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423080044/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/240221-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Directions-No7.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423080150/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/document-collections/covid-19-coronavirus-business-and-community-activity     Tasmania:   Residential Aged Care Facilities - No. 11 came into effect on the 1 March 2021 and remains current as of the 23rd April 2021.   In Tasmania, visits to residential aged care facilities are permitted for people providing care and support, with the following restrictions.   Visitors must not:   have any symptoms of COVID-19  been in an area or premises identified as medium or high-risk for COVID-19 in the previous 14 days  had contact with anyone known to have COVID-19, or reasonably suspected of having COVID-19, within the previous 14 days (except as part of their employment while wearing effective personal protective equipment).    Operators of aged care facilities must screen all people (except people attending for emergency management reasons) before they enter the premises.   Operators of aged care facilities are required to record the contact details for everyone who remains on site for 15 minutes or more    Residents may leave the facility.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423080824/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/aged-care-facility-visits   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326083819/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/126294/Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-No.-11.pdf     Northern Territory:   COVID-19 Directions (No. 40) 2020 Directions for Aged Care Facilities were signed on the 24th June 202 and remain current on the 23rd April 2021.    The direct provides that visitors to residential aged care facilities are allow except:   While there are no limits on the total number of visits allow, visitor should generally visit one at a time.   A visitor must not have had contact with a positive case within the last 14 days; must not have symptoms consistent with COVID-19; must generally have an up-to-date vaccination against influenza, if the vaccination was available to the person  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423081313/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/chief-health-officer-directions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326084231/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/898953/cho-directions-no40-directions-aged-care-facilities.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423081313/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/chief-health-officer-directions       Australian Capital Territory:   The Australian Capital Territory COVID-19 Government website states that   “This means that you can visit your family member or close friend in an aged care facility for the purposes of providing care and support.  You are not limited in the number of hours you can spend with your relative or friend.  However, you cannot visit aged care facilities if you:  Have returned from overseas in the last 14 days.  Have been in a geographical area of risk in the last 14 days.  Have been in contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days.  Have a temperature higher than 37.5 degrees or history of fever (e.g. night sweats or chills).  Symptoms of a respiratory infection such as a cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, loss of smell or loss of taste.”  This is enforced by the Public Health (Residential Aged Care Facilities) Emergency Direction 2021 (No 2) that came into effect on 7 February 2021 and remains current as of the 23rd April 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423082330/https://www.legislation.act.gov.au/ni/2021-56/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423082111/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/stay-safe-and-healthy/aged-care/advice-for-visitors-to-aged-care-facilities

Snap lockdown - ""Perth and Peel entered a snap three-day lockdown from midnight Friday after a Victorian man, who tested positive to Covid-19, spent five days in the community while infectious after leaving hotel quarantine."" ... ""Visitors will be barred from hospitals or residential aged care or disability facilities, unless there are exceptional circumstances.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425131432/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/apr/23/perth-to-enter-snap-three-day-lockdown-after-covid-spreads-from-hotel-quarantine-into-community

The Western Australian government announced that people in Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region, and Rottnest Island must enter into a lockdown from 12.01am Saturday, April 24, to limit any potential spread of COVID-19. The lock-down was announced in response to a single case of community transmission of COVID-19.  An international arrival tested positive to COVID-19 after being released following 14 days of hotel quarantine.  This international arrival then infected a close contact.    The lock-down announced was planned for 3 days, and is scheduled to end at 12.01am Tuesday, April 27.    No visitors were allowed to residential aged care facilities during this period (except for compassionate reasons and advocacy).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064043/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-metro-and-peel-enter-3-day-lockdown

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Western Australian government announced that the Perth, Peel Region, and Rottnest Island lockdown would end as planned from 12.01am, Tuesday 27 April.  Further that a post-lockdown transition would be in place until 12.01am, Saturday 1 May.      SPECIFICATION OF A FURTHER PERIOD UNDER THE VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES (STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST)) DIRECTIONS came into effect at 12.01 am on Tuesday, 27 April 2021.    This direction maintained the previous restrictions on visitors to residential aged care facilities. No visitors were allowed to residential aged care facilities (with limited compassionate and advocacy exemptions).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502073200/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/end-of-lockdown-perth-and-peel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502080119/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Specification-of-a-further-period-under-paragraph-3.pdf

As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES (STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST)) DIRECTIONS (No 3) came into effect at 12.0 I am on 1 May 2021  In a modest easing of restrictions, a resident of an aged care facility may now have one visitor per day.  End of life circumstance are exempt from the one visitor per day restriction.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502082103/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/perth-and-peel-lockdown-restrictions-ease-further   http://web.archive.org/web/20210502091033/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions-No3.pdf

Western Australia  As published on the Wester Australian Government COVID-19 website, The Perth and Peel post-lockdown restrictions will be significantly eased from 12.01am Saturday, May 1, with a small number of transitional measures in place until 12.01am, Saturday 8 May to see out the full 14-day incubation period.    VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES (STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST)) DIRECTIONS (No 3) came into effect at 12.0 I am on 1 May 2021  In a modest easing of restrictions, a resident of an aged care facility may now have one visitor per day.  End of life circumstance are exempt from the one visitor per day restriction. This remains up to date as of the 7th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507103119/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502091033/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-04/Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions-No3.pdf     New South Wales  The NSW Premier released a media statement on the 6th May 2010 announcing the introduction of new restrictions for the Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains.  This announcement was in response to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.    In NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer.  Current advice for facilities within the Greater Sydney area, including metropolitan Sydney, Nepean Blue Mountains, Central Coast and Wollongong, the following rules apply until further notice:  A maximum of 2 visitors may be permitted per resident, per day  All visitors must wear a surgical mask  Visits should take place outdoors where possible.    This is up to date as of the 7th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210507121312/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507120917/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507100126/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/covid-19-restrictions-update-6-may    Coded as a 3T reflecting that only one visitor per day is allowed within Western Australia residential aged care facilities.

Western Australia  VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES (STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST)) DIRECTIONS (No 3) came into effect at 12.01 am on 8 May 2021 and continued to be in effect until 12.01 am on 15 May 2021.   In a modest easing of restrictions, a resident of an aged care facility may now have up to four visitors per day.  End of life circumstance are exempt from the one visitor per day restriction.  This easing was in response to no recent community transmission of COVID-19.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210511033531/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/070521-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions-No4.pdf     Western Australia no longer meets criteria for a level 3 code.  Some, but not all, other Australian states and territories continue to implement narrow required policy protections of the elderly in response to COVID-19.  For example, below is included a description Victoria’s continuing required narrow policy restrictions.  New South Wales currently has no required restrictions.  Instead NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements.  Therefore code changed to 2T.     Victoria:   As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, “From 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021, Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe settings.”…” There are no limits on the purpose of visits, the number of visitors or the length of the visit to care facilities.”…”You must wear a face mask when visiting care facilities. “Care facilities must comply with the two square metre rule that limits the number of people that can be in a shared communal space at the same time. Density limits do not apply in bedrooms of aged care facilities…  You will not be permitted to enter a care facility if you are a worker or visitor and you:   are a diagnosed person or close contact under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions;   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, arrived in Australia from overseas (other than on a quarantine-free flight from an overseas location designated by the Australian Government as a green travel zone);   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, had known contact with a confirmed case (except in the course of your employment while wearing the appropriate level of personal protective equipment in the circumstances);    have SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms; or   if you are a visitor – have been tested for COVID-19 and are awaiting your test results.  ”  This policy is up to date as of the 17th May 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517095721/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/visiting-care-facilities   New South Wales  In NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer.  On the 10th May 2021, the NSW Government announced in a press release on the NSW COVID-19 government website that the advice for facilities Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains) was that visitors were recommended to be limited to 2 people per day.  This advice was a continuation of the previous advice issued on the 6th May 2021.  The policy was put in place as part of a suite of restrictions responding to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.    On the 17th May, as published on the NSW Government COVD-19 website, the Chief Health Officer relaxed her advice for residential aged care facilities in NSW.  The relaxation of advice was in response to there being “no further local transmission of COVID-19 in NSW,”.   “Visitors  Visitors must not enter the facility at all if they:  have been to any close or casual contact locations in NSW or Interstate places of high concern  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result  From 1 June to 30 September 2021 visitors should not enter an aged care facility if they have not received a dose of the 2021 influenza vaccine, unless they meet the criteria under the exceptional and special circumstances.    Residents  Residents who are attending outings and excursions should ensure that:  avoid crowded indoor areas, such as shopping centres and restaurants  the event complies with the current Public Health Gathering Restriction Order 2021”    This remains up to date as of the 17th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517102526/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517101832/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/pages/20210509_00.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507121312/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx

Instead NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements.  Therefore code remains at 2T.     Victoria:   As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, “From 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021, Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe settings.”…” There are no limits on the purpose of visits, the number of visitors or the length of the visit to care facilities.”…”You must wear a face mask when visiting care facilities. “Care facilities must comply with the two square metre rule that limits the number of people that can be in a shared communal space at the same time. Density limits do not apply in bedrooms of aged care facilities…  You will not be permitted to enter a care facility if you are a worker or visitor and you:   are a diagnosed person or close contact under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions;   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, arrived in Australia from overseas (other than on a quarantine-free flight from an overseas location designated by the Australian Government as a green travel zone);   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, had known contact with a confirmed case (except in the course of your employment while wearing the appropriate level of personal protective equipment in the circumstances);    have SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms; or   if you are a visitor – have been tested for COVID-19 and are awaiting your test results.  ”  This policy is up to date as of the 17th May 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517095721/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/visiting-care-facilities   New South Wales  In NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer.  On the 10th May 2021, the NSW Government announced in a press release on the NSW COVID-19 government website that the advice for facilities Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains) was that visitors were recommended to be limited to 2 people per day.  This advice was a continuation of the previous advice issued on the 6th May 2021.  The policy was put in place as part of a suite of restrictions responding to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.    On the 17th May, as published on the NSW Government COVD-19 website, the Chief Health Officer relaxed her advice for residential aged care facilities in NSW.  The relaxation of advice was in response to there being “no further local transmission of COVID-19 in NSW,”.   “Visitors  Visitors must not enter the facility at all if they:  have been to any close or casual contact locations in NSW or Interstate places of high concern  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result  From 1 June to 30 September 2021 visitors should not enter an aged care facility if they have not received a dose of the 2021 influenza vaccine, unless they meet the criteria under the exceptional and special circumstances.    Residents  Residents who are attending outings and excursions should ensure that:  avoid crowded indoor areas, such as shopping centres and restaurants  the event complies with the current Public Health Gathering Restriction Order 2021”    This remains up to date as of the 17th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517102526/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517101832/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/pages/20210509_00.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507121312/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx

Western Australia  A media announcement published on the 13th May 2021 state that “The Perth and Peel regions return to pre-lockdown life from 12.01am Saturday 15 May, following the latest public health advice.  No additional cases have been detected in the Perth and Peel regions since the detection of the last community case on Saturday, May 1.” In part, this means that “Visitor limits for patients in hospital, aged care or disability facilities will be lifted”  The VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES (STAY AT HOME AND CLOSURE (PERTH, PEEL AND ROTTNEST)) DIRECTIONS (No 3) were repealed at 12.01 am on 15 May 2021.  As such, the VISITORS TO RESIDENTIAL AGED CARE FACILITIES DIRECTIONS (NO 7) is now apply to the Perth and Peel Regions (as well as the rest of Western Australia).  This direction stipulates that a person not enter a residential aged care facility if they: have been outside of Australian within the last 14 days; have been in contact with a positive case within the last 14 days, have any symptoms consistent with COVID-19; or have not had an updated influenza vaccination (with some exceptions).    This remains up to date as of the 17th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210514212351/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/pre-lockdown-life-resumes-perth-and-peel-regions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210423080044/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/240221-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Directions-No7.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210511033531/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/070521-Visitors-to-Residential-Aged-Care-Facilities-Stay-at-Home-and-Closure-Perth-Peel-and-Rottnest-Directions-No4.pdf  Like Western Australia, some, but not all, other Australian states and territories continue to implement narrow required policy protections of the elderly in response to COVID-19.  For example, below is included a description Victoria’s continuing required narrow policy restrictions.  New South Wales currently has no required restrictions.  Instead NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements.  Therefore code remains at 2T.     Victoria:   As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, “From 11:59pm on Friday 9 April 2021, Victoria has further relaxed its COVIDSafe settings.”…” There are no limits on the purpose of visits, the number of visitors or the length of the visit to care facilities.”…”You must wear a face mask when visiting care facilities. “Care facilities must comply with the two square metre rule that limits the number of people that can be in a shared communal space at the same time. Density limits do not apply in bedrooms of aged care facilities…  You will not be permitted to enter a care facility if you are a worker or visitor and you:   are a diagnosed person or close contact under the Diagnosed Persons and Close Contacts Directions;   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, arrived in Australia from overseas (other than on a quarantine-free flight from an overseas location designated by the Australian Government as a green travel zone);   have, during the 14 days prior to entry, had known contact with a confirmed case (except in the course of your employment while wearing the appropriate level of personal protective equipment in the circumstances);    have SARS-CoV-2 Symptoms; or   if you are a visitor – have been tested for COVID-19 and are awaiting your test results.  ”  This policy is up to date as of the 17th May 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517095721/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/visiting-care-facilities   New South Wales  In NSW Residential aged care facilities are required to consider the advice of the Chief Health Officer in their visitor and access policies and requirements. Individual operators may choose to implement their own decisions about access restrictions and screening requirements, having regard to the advice of the Chief Health Officer.  On the 10th May 2021, the NSW Government announced in a press release on the NSW COVID-19 government website that the advice for facilities Greater Sydney region (including Wollongong, Central Coast and Blue Mountains) was that visitors were recommended to be limited to 2 people per day.  This advice was a continuation of the previous advice issued on the 6th May 2021.  The policy was put in place as part of a suite of restrictions responding to the discovery of community transmission of COVID-19 from and unknown source.    On the 17th May, as published on the NSW Government COVD-19 website, the Chief Health Officer relaxed her advice for residential aged care facilities in NSW.  The relaxation of advice was in response to there being “no further local transmission of COVID-19 in NSW,”.   “Visitors  Visitors must not enter the facility at all if they:  have been to any close or casual contact locations in NSW or Interstate places of high concern  have COVID-19 symptoms - fever (37. 5°C or higher) or symptoms of COVID-19  are a close contact of a person with confirmed COVID-19 and are within their self-isolation period  live in a household with a person who is currently self-isolating  are waiting for a COVID-19 test result  From 1 June to 30 September 2021 visitors should not enter an aged care facility if they have not received a dose of the 2021 influenza vaccine, unless they meet the criteria under the exceptional and special circumstances.    Residents  Residents who are attending outings and excursions should ensure that:  avoid crowded indoor areas, such as shopping centres and restaurants  the event complies with the current Public Health Gathering Restriction Order 2021”    This remains up to date as of the 17th May 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210517102526/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/public-health-orders.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517101832/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/pages/20210509_00.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507121312/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Pages/racf-latest-advice.aspx

No change.    Social distancing and other public measures in restaurants and cafes remain in place. Cinemas are only allowed to operate at 80% capacity.    ""1. Operators or operators of food premises are required to procure  Bruhealth QR codes specific to their premises and subsequently print  the QR code and affixed to the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned  by the customer before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Food premises can operate at normal capacity rates;  3. Buffet food preparation is allowed on condition  food must be served by employees of restaurants, cafes or  food court;  4. Body temperature check must be done before entering the premises  food;  5. Owners of food premises must insure their employees  who handles and prepares food for constant wear  nose and mouth cover (face mask);  6. Unhealthy food premise employees are advised not to attend  working;  7. Ensure physical and social distancing including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Food premises are not allowed to increase the seating capacity  dine-in from normal capacity;  7.2 Food premises to provide special spaces or queues for  takeaway service;  7.3 Food premises to provide hand sanitiser;  7.4 Food premises are required to comply with internal guidelines  cleaning and sanitation of the premises.  8. Any food premise operators found not  comply with the aforementioned conditions, may be subject to action  law under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. Entrepreneurs of food premises are requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    ""1. Cinema owners or operators are required to obtain a QR code  Bruhealth specific to their premises and subsequently print a QR code  and affixed in the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned by  visitors before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Limit the number of visitors allowed to enter at any one time to 80% of the total normal capacity of the space  sitting cinema concerned;  3. Body temperature check must be done before entering the cinema;  4. Cinema owners or operators must ensure employees  them to always wear a nose and mouth mask (face mask);  5. Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    See the Ministry of Home Affairs' guidelines on restaurants and cinemas, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/ns5m33kvui5uyen/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANRESTORANFasa4.pdf  AND on  https://www.dropbox.com/s/zbabj0iiywl9j5h/BRN-20201017-MOHA-GARISPANDUANCINEMAFasa3.pdf

No change.    Social distancing and other public measures in restaurants and cafes remain in place. Cinemas are only allowed to operate at 80% capacity.    ""1. Operators or operators of food premises are required to procure  Bruhealth QR codes specific to their premises and subsequently print  the QR code and affixed to the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned  by the customer before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Food premises can operate at normal capacity rates;  3. Buffet food preparation is allowed on condition  food must be served by employees of restaurants, cafes or  food court;  4. Body temperature check must be done before entering the premises  food;  5. Owners of food premises must insure their employees  who handles and prepares food for constant wear  nose and mouth cover (face mask);  6. Unhealthy food premise employees are advised not to attend  working;  7. Ensure physical and social distancing including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Food premises are not allowed to increase the seating capacity  dine-in from normal capacity;  7.2 Food premises to provide special spaces or queues for  takeaway service;  7.3 Food premises to provide hand sanitiser;  7.4 Food premises are required to comply with internal guidelines  cleaning and sanitation of the premises.  8. Any food premise operators found not  comply with the aforementioned conditions, may be subject to action  law under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. Entrepreneurs of food premises are requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time.""    ""1. Cinema owners or operators are required to obtain a QR code  Bruhealth specific to their premises and subsequently print a QR code  and affixed in the entrance area of ??the premises to be scanned by  visitors before entering and immediately before leaving the premises;  2. Limit the number of visitors allowed to enter at any one time to 80% of the total normal capacity of the space  sitting cinema concerned;  3. Body temperature check must be done before entering the cinema;  4. Cinema owners or operators must ensure employees  them to always wear a nose and mouth mask (face mask);  5. Unhealthy cinema employees are advised not to attend  working;  6. Ensuring that the film will be shown will delay the screening time  after the end of a film screening to allow the cinema  clean the seats and surroundings of the cinema (fully sanitize);  7. Ensure physical and social incarceration including execution of instructions  made by the Government such as:-  7.1 Ensure the physical incarceration of cinema visitors to a minimum  one (1) seat. Customers who come in on a regular basis  groups are allowed to sit nearby;  7.2 Cinemas to display notice of the maximum amount of incoming capacity  at a time in an appropriate place;  7.3 Cinemas are not allowed to increase the seating capacity of  normal capacity; and  7.4 Cinema to provide hand sanitiser;  8. Any cinema owner or operator found to be non-compliant  the conditions mentioned earlier, may be subject to legal action  under the Infectious Diseases Act Chapter 204; and  9. The owner or operator of the cinema is requested to provide  cooperation to comply with the instructions set by the Government  from time to time."" No change. As mentioned in the entry on 09 Feb, the Ministry of Health reiterates its advisories given the then-impending Chinese New Year celebrations,  ""Those with large families are permitted to hold private events at banquet halls in hotels or restaurants provided that Mass Gathering guidelines are adhered to, including provision of hand sanitizers and conducting temperature checks at the premises. If the number of family members is huge, limit attendance to a maximum of 350 people.""    The number allowed was increased to 1,000 people, on 8th March. (See https://archive.vn/VEyvh)    The Ministry continues to encourage safe distancing and other measures, including the limitation of events that are held to 2 hours.    See Ministry of Health's reiteration, archived at https://archive.vn/c7CpW  See also https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, the Ministry of Health's guidelines on mass gatherings, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/l0qb3n0bg8n31oz/BRN-20200924-Guidelines_MassGathering.pdf

No change.    As mentioned in the entry on 09 Feb, the Ministry of Health reiterates its advisories given the then-impending Chinese New Year celebrations,  ""Those with large families are permitted to hold private events at banquet halls in hotels or restaurants provided that Mass Gathering guidelines are adhered to, including provision of hand sanitizers and conducting temperature checks at the premises. If the number of family members is huge, limit attendance to a maximum of 350 people.""    The government reissued calls for the public to be vigilant in light of the then-impending Hari Raya Aidilfitri celebrations on 20th April, 2021.    ""Hosts are advised to schedule private events at home appropriately so as to prevent overcrowding at any one time, taking into account the size of one's home;     Large families with limited home space and who wish to organise a private event are advised to hold the event at a hall and adhering to the current guideline, including following the current mass gathering limit and scanning BruHealth QR code when entering the hall;    Anyone who are unwell or having symptoms are not allowed to visit or be visited by their family members;     The practice of shaking hands and hugs during Eid are not recommended; it is sufficient to give a gesture of greeting by placing the hand over the chest, smiling, or nodding the head as a sign of respect and greeting. Avoid as much as possible any attempts to touch or make physical contact with others;     Ensure good and well maintained personal and environmental hygiene especially the hands;    Practice correct cough and sneeze etiquette at all times; and    Avoid from sharing food and drink utensils such as spoon, fork, plates and glasses.""      The current maximum mass gathering size allowed was increased to 1,000 people, on 8th March. (See https://archive.vn/VEyvh)    The Ministry also continues to encourage safe distancing and other measures, including the limitation of events that are held to 2 hours.    See Ministry of Health's reiteration for Chinese New Year, archived at https://archive.vn/c7CpW  See Ministry of Health's guidelines/reiteration for Hari Raya Aidilfitri, archived at https://archive.vn/rgpTk  See also https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, the Ministry of Health's guidelines on mass gatherings, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/l0qb3n0bg8n31oz/BRN-20200924-Guidelines_MassGathering.pdf

No changes in policy.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 26 April, public transport is operating.    The Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' previous guidelines from September 2020 remains in force:    ""Public Transport Operators are allowed to operate 100% vehicle seating capacity. However, Public Transport Operators as well passengers are still required to adhere to the prescribed guidelines  by the Ministry of Health.  1. Scan the Bruhealth QR code before entering Public transportation. Only Green and Yellow Codes are allowed to use Public Transport;  ii. Use of face mask when  in Public Transport vehicles and along the way;  iii. Avoid physical contact.  iv. Avoid chatting while inside vehicle.  v. Check body temperature before boarding vehicle.  vi. For bus passengers, must sit along the way.""      See Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications' Guidelines (in Malay), last updated 07 Sep 2020, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/xj97s2roah5u1la/BRN-20200907-PengemaskinianGarispanduan.pdf  See US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/1vwNj

No change.    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 26 April, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for more information regarding Brunei’s pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    Per the Ministry of Health,   From 20 March 2020, all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam  through any points of entry are required to undergo mandatory selfisolation for 14 days at a government-designated facility immediately  upon arrival to the country.  i) Self-isolation at private homes are not permitted.  ii) This include all visitors and foreign workers arriving in the  country.  iii) All foreign nationals including foreign workers arriving in the  country are required to bear fully the cost of mandatory selfisolation (including accommodation and meals) and laboratory  test for SARS-CoV-2 ($1000 per test).  iv) Foreign workers must submit special entry application for foreign  workers before arriving in Brunei Darussalam.     Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/ErfBU  See the Ministry of Health's guidelines on travel, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/mpd9geybded3b1h/BRN-undated-Guidelines_Travel.pdf  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change.    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 05 May, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for more information regarding Brunei’s pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/MmKas  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 26 April,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200.  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/1vwNj

A:    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    No significant changes. However, the Minister of Health has reported that over 11 thousand people have received their first Covid-19 vaccine dose.    See the Star's report, archived at https://archive.vn/NhWzo

A,C:  (Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    On May 3, ""[the] Minister of Health has received the second dose of the COVID-19 injection at Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha Hospital this morning, along with the Permanent Secretary, Deputy Permanent Secretary, Head of Departments, senior officers, officers and staffs at the Ministry of Health; as well as officers consisting of frontliners.    Since the implementation of the National Vaccination Program for COVID-19 began on 3 April 2021, a total of 14,876 people have received the COVID-19 vaccine, of which 14,526 people have received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine, while 350 people have received the second dose of COVID-19 vaccine.    At present, the administration of COVID-19 vaccine is still being implemented for Phase One, consisting of frontliners, students studying abroad and senior citizens aged 60 and above. Priority is given to frontliners and especially the elderly because frontliners have a higher risk of being infected with COVID-19 and the elderly have a higher risk of getting more severe complications of COVID-19 infection. Without COVID-19 vaccine injections, clinical data obtained from around the world show those aged 60 and above are more likely to get the effects of more severe infections that require treatment in the Intensive Care Unit including respiratory assistance and have a higher risk of death as a result of the COVID-19 infection. Scientific studies have also shown that injection of COVID-19 vaccine can reduce the risk of COVID-19 infection for the elderly and frontliners.""    Separate to the press release by the Ministry of Health, the Minister of Health also stated that “Brunei Darussalam will receive 200,000 doses of the Moderna vaccine and 300,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, in addition to more than 100,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine in several batches. This will help to cover the COVID-19 vaccination for 70 per cent of the population by end of this year,” confirming the future expansion of Brunei's vaccination programme to use the Pfizer-BioNTech (tozinameran) and Moderna (mRNA-1273) vaccines, and the use of these two vaccines will account for 55% of Brunei's population.    On May 5, it was further announced that ""the number of people [in Brunei] receiving their second dose of vaccine has reached 862, while 15,043 have just received their first dose"".    See:  the Ministry of Health's press release (03 May), archived at https://archive.vn/u9EH5  the Borneo Bulletin report (03 May) entitled ""Moderna vaccine on the way"", archived at https://archive.vn/PgWZC  the Scoop report (03 May) entitled ""55% of Brunei population to receive Pfizer, Moderna jabs"", archived at https://archive.vn/4aWdG  the Borneo Bulletin report (05 May) entitled ""Over 15,000 inoculated under vaccination programme"", archived at https://archive.vn/K6iWQ    NB: Although this was previously reported as 3G as the Ministry of Education encouraged students heading overseas to ""register"" themselves for the vaccination, no such vaccinations can be confirmed to be carried out. Additionally, the Ministry of Health's press release (archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43, dated 21 May 2021) suggesting that students can finally get the vaccination via the QueUp app indicates that the vaccination of students heading overseas for further studies have not been carried out until at least 21st May.

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above;  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    NB: This is coded as 4G; however, group B (clinically vulnerable groups which are non-elderly) are not eligible to receive the vaccination in Brunei as of yet, as they are categorised under Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (Brunei is currently in Phase 1 of its vaccination strategy).    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    The Ministry currently operates an opt-in programme for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, due to the very low risk of thrombotic thrombocytopenia and related events the vaccine causes; alongside the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy (where the Sinopharm vaccine is still being offered to the groups under Phase 1; and the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is routinely used in individuals aged 60 and above).    According to the Borneo Bulletin (owned by the Government of Brunei), ""[u]nder the opt-in programme for the Oxford-Astrazeneca COVID-19 Vaccine, the AstraZeneca vaccine will be made available free of charge to all citizens, permanent residents, and foreign long-term residents in the country from May 6–29. This is made available on a voluntary basis and offered to all individuals above 18 on a-first-come-first-served basis until May 29 or until all available doses have been utilised.""    Additionally, ""[t]his opt-in programme will run alongside to the prioritisation phases outlined in the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy and allow individuals aged between 18 to 59 wishing to receive the vaccine earlier than they otherwise would be able to, the opportunity to do so with the AstraZeneca vaccine""    Furthermore, the report by Borneo Bulletin also mentions that ""[v]accination with other brands (at least including Moderna and Pfizer, as per the Health Minister's comments on 3rd May) for the general population is expected to commence in the fourth quarter this year"".    See:  the Borneo Bulletin report (03 May) entitled ""Moderna vaccine on the way"", archived at https://archive.vn/PgWZC  the Scoop report (03 May) entitled ""55% of Brunei population to receive Pfizer, Moderna jabs"", archived at https://archive.vn/4aWdG  the Borneo Bulletin report (10 May) entitled ""AstraZeneca: What you need to know"", archived at https://archive.vn/cOPsb

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above;  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    NB: This is coded as 4G; however, group B (clinically vulnerable groups which are non-elderly) are not eligible to receive the vaccination in Brunei as of yet, as they are categorised under Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (Brunei is currently in Phase 1 of its vaccination strategy).  NB2: Although this was previously reported that students heading overseas are also getting vaccinated at this point in time, as the Ministry of Education had encouraged such students to ""register"" themselves for the vaccination, no such vaccinations can be confirmed to be carried out. Additionally, the Ministry of Health's press release (archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43, dated 21 May 2021), suggesting that students can finally get the vaccination via the QueUp app, indicates that the vaccination of students heading overseas for further studies have not been carried out until at least 21st May.    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There are no significant updates since the last entry. As mentioned in the last entry, the Ministry currently operates an opt-in programme for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, due to the very low risk of thrombotic thrombocytopenia and related events the vaccine causes; alongside the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy (where the Sinopharm vaccine is still being offered to the groups under Phase 1; and the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is routinely used in individuals aged 60 and above).    According to the Borneo Bulletin (owned by the Government of Brunei), ""[u]nder the opt-in programme for the Oxford-Astrazeneca COVID-19 Vaccine, the AstraZeneca vaccine will be made available free of charge to all citizens, permanent residents, and foreign long-term residents in the country from May 6–29. This is made available on a voluntary basis and offered to all individuals above 18 on a-first-come-first-served basis until May 29 or until all available doses have been utilised.""    See:  the Borneo Bulletin report (10 May) entitled ""AstraZeneca: What you need to know"", archived at https://archive.vn/cOPsb

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    Vaccinations using the Sinopharm vaccine is now definitively open to students travelling abroad for studies. According to a Ministry of Health press release dated on 21 May, ""[it] would like to inform the public, especially students who will be studying abroad, that those who wish to receive the COVID-19 vaccine, which is the Sinopharm vaccine can get the vaccine injection at the Berakas Health Screening Center during office hours.    They can make an appointment for the Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine injection via the Queup application.""    This was also reported by the Scoop, ""During a press briefing on Friday (21 May), the health minister said students who will travel soon will be inoculated with the Chinese-made vaccine as the interval period between the first and second doses is 21 days.  YB Dato Seri Setia Dr Hj Md Isham Hj Jaafar said students should wait 14 days after their second Sinopharm COVID-19 shot before boarding a flight as it takes time for antibodies to kick in.""    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43T  See the Scoop report, archived at https://archive.vn/XJo2s

After Yingkou (Liaoning), Shenyang (Liaoning), Hefei (Anhui), and Liuan (Anhui), Guangzhou (Guangdong) became the fourth city which recently recorded a local case. The case was confirmed in 21 May: the local government marked the area in where the patient lives as [mid-risk] the following day. By 23 May, there are 23 [mid-risk] areas: one in Guangzhou, one in Hefei, six in Liuan, 11 in Yingkou, and four in Shenyang. Other areas are [low-risk], where life has to a large extent back to normal.    https://archive.vn/6qMHC
